title: Historical Volatility
notes: This equation calculates historical volatility from price data. sigma_hist represents the historical volatility
column5: n is the number of observations
column6: S_i are the prices
column7: and mu is the average log return. Historical volatility is a simple but widely used volatility estimator.

title: Exponentially Weighted Moving Average
notes: This equation defines the EWMA volatility model. sigma_EWMA represents the EWMA volatility estimate
column5: lambda is the decay factor (typically 0.94-0.97)
column6: sigma_{t-1}^2 is the previous variance
column7: and r_t is the current return. EWMA gives more weight to recent observations.

title: GARCH(1
main_category: sigma_t^2 = omega + alpha * epsilon_{t-1}^2 + beta * sigma_{t-1}^2
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: This equation defines the GARCH(1
column6: 1) model for conditional volatility. sigma_t^2 represents the conditional variance
column8: alpha is the ARCH coefficient (response to shocks)
column9: epsilon_{t-1}^2 is the previous squared shock
column10: and beta is the GARCH coefficient (persistence). GARCH captures volatility clustering.

title: GARCH(p
main_category: sigma_t^2 = omega + sum_{i=1}^q alpha_i * epsilon_{t-i}^2 + sum_{j=1}^p beta_j * sigma_{t-j}^2
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: This equation defines the general GARCH(p
column6: q) model. The conditional variance depends on q past squared shocks and p past variances. GARCH(p
column7: q) provides more flexibility than GARCH(1

title: EGARCH Model
equation_latex: ln(sigma_t^2) = omega + alpha * (|epsilon_{t-1}| / sigma_{t-1} - sqrt(2/pi)) + gamma * (epsilon_{t-1} / sigma_{t-1}) + beta * ln(sigma_{t-1}^2)
notes: This equation defines the EGARCH model
column5: which models log variance. EGARCH captures asymmetric volatility response (leverage effect) through the gamma term. Positive shocks (gamma > 0) increase volatility more than negative shocks in equity markets.

title: GJR-GARCH Model
equation_latex: sigma_t^2 = omega + alpha * epsilon_{t-1}^2 + gamma * epsilon_{t-1}^2 * I(epsilon_{t-1} < 0) + beta * sigma_{t-1}^2
notes: This equation defines the GJR-GARCH model
column5: which captures asymmetric volatility. I(epsilon_{t-1} < 0) is an indicator function that is 1 for negative shocks and 0 otherwise. The gamma term allows different responses to positive and negative shocks.

title: Stochastic Volatility Model
equation_latex: dS_t = mu * S_t * dt + sqrt(v_t) * S_t * dW_t^S
main_category: dv_t = kappa * (theta - v_t) * dt + sigma_v * sqrt(v_t) * dW_t^v
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: These equations define the Heston stochastic volatility model. dS_t is the asset price SDE with volatility sqrt(v_t)
column6: and dv_t is the volatility SDE with mean reversion speed kappa
column8: and volatility of volatility sigma_v. The two Brownian motions may be correlated.

title: Heston Correlation
notes: This equation defines the correlation between asset price and volatility shocks in the Heston model. rho represents the correlation coefficient
column5: which is typically negative for equities (leverage effect). Negative correlation means negative price shocks increase volatility.

title: Heston Characteristic Function
main_category: t) = exp(i * u * ln(S_0) + i * u * (r - q) * t + kappa * theta * (i * u - rho * sigma_v * i * u - d) * t / sigma_v^2 - (2 * kappa * theta / sigma_v^2) * ln(1 - g * exp(-d * t)) / (1 - g))
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: This equation defines the characteristic function of log returns under the Heston model. The characteristic function is used for fast Fourier transform (FFT) option pricing. The parameters d and g depend on the model parameters and the Fourier variable u.

title: SABR Model
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: These equations define the SABR stochastic volatility model. dF_t is the forward rate dynamics with stochastic volatility alpha_t
column6: beta controls the level dependence
column7: nu is the volatility of volatility
column8: and the two Brownian motions are correlated. SABR is widely used for volatility smile modeling.

title: SABR Implied Volatility
equation_latex: sigma_BSM(K) = (alpha / (F^{1-beta})) * (z / x(z)) * (1 + ((1-beta)^2 * alpha^2 / (24 * F^{2-2beta}) + rho * beta * nu * alpha / (4 * F^{1-beta}) + (2 - 3 * rho^2) * nu^2 / 24) * T)
notes: This equation gives the implied volatility under the SABR model. sigma_BSM represents the Black-Scholes implied volatility
column5: which depends on strike K
column6: forward F
column8: and SABR parameters. The formula captures the volatility smile observed in options markets.

title: Local Volatility Model
notes: T) * sqrt(1 + 2 * r * T / (K * sigma_BS(K
column5: T)) * (d_1 / (sigma_BS(K
column6: T) * sqrt(T))))
column8: This equation defines the local volatility surface from implied volatility. sigma_loc represents the local volatility
column9: sigma_BS is the Black-Scholes implied volatility
column11: and d_1 is the Black-Scholes parameter. Local volatility models are calibrated to match the entire volatility surface.

title: Dupire Formula
main_category: T)^2 = 2 * (partial C/partial T + r * K * partial C/partial K) / (K^2 * partial^2 C/partial K^2)
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling
column5: This equation defines the local volatility function from option prices (Dupire formula). sigma_loc represents the local volatility
column6: C is the call option price
column8: and the derivatives are with respect to strike K and maturity T. Dupire's formula is fundamental to local volatility modeling.

title: Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the Poisson process for jump arrivals. N_t represents the number of jumps by time t
column5: which follows a Poisson distribution with mean lambda * t. The Poisson process has independent and stationary increments
column6: making it suitable for modeling rare events.

title: Poisson Process Probability
equation_latex: P(N_t = n) = exp(-lambda * t) * (lambda * t)^n / n!
notes: This equation gives the probability of n jumps occurring by time t. The Poisson distribution has mean lambda * t and variance lambda * t. The Poisson process is the standard model for discrete events like defaults or jumps in asset prices.

title: Compound Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the compound Poisson process. X_t represents the accumulated jump size
column5: N_t is the number of jumps (Poisson process)
column6: and Y_i are i.i.d. jump sizes. Compound Poisson processes are used for modeling cumulative losses from rare events.

title: Jump-Diffusion Model
equation_latex: dS_t = mu * S_t * dt + sigma * S_t * dW_t + S_t * dJ_t
notes: This equation defines the Merton jump-diffusion model. dS_t is the asset price change
column5: mu is the drift
column6: sigma is the diffusion volatility
column8: and dJ_t is the jump component. Jump-diffusion models capture fat tails and skewness in return distributions.

title: Jump Component
notes: This equation defines the jump component in the jump-diffusion model. Y is the log jump size (typically normal)
column5: exp(Y) - 1 is the proportional jump size
column6: and dN_t is the Poisson process increment. Jumps occur randomly with intensity lambda and have random sizes.

title: Merton Jump-Diffusion Solution
equation_latex: S_t = S_0 * exp((mu - 0.5 * sigma^2 - lambda * (exp(mu_J + 0.5 * sigma_J^2) - 1)) * t + sigma * W_t + sum_{i=1}^{N_t} Y_i)
notes: This equation gives the solution to the Merton jump-diffusion SDE. S_t represents the asset price
column5: mu_J and sigma_J are the mean and volatility of log jump sizes Y_i
column6: and N_t is the Poisson process. The solution shows that log prices are normal with jumps.

title: Kou Double Exponential Jump Model
notes: This equation defines the Kou double exponential jump size distribution. Y_i represents the log jump size
column5: which follows an asymmetric double exponential distribution. The positive jumps have rate eta_1 with probability p
column6: and negative jumps have rate eta_2 with probability 1-p. This model captures skewness and kurtosis.

title: Variance Gamma Process
notes: This equation defines the Variance Gamma (VG) process. X_t represents the log return
column5: theta is the drift
column6: sigma is the volatility
column8: and W_{G_t} is Brownian motion evaluated at the Gamma time change. VG is a pure jump process with infinite activity.

title: CGMY Process
notes: G * G_t))
column5: Advanced Topics - Jump Processes
column6: This equation defines the Carr-Geman-Madan-Yor (CGMY) process. X_t represents the log return
column8: G and M control the small and large jump behavior
column10: and Gamma is the incomplete Gamma function. CGMY is a flexible Lévy process.

title: Lévy Process
equation_latex: X_t = X_0 + mu * t + sigma * W_t + J_t
notes: This equation defines a general Lévy process. X_t represents the process value
column5: mu is the drift
column6: sigma * W_t is the Brownian motion component
column7: and J_t is the pure jump component. Lévy processes have independent and stationary increments and include many popular models as special cases.

title: Lévy Measure
notes: This equation defines the Lévy measure for jump processes. nu(dx) represents the intensity of jumps of size dx
column5: lambda is the jump intensity
column6: and f_Y(x) is the jump size density. The Lévy measure characterizes the jump component of a Lévy process.

title: Characteristic Function of Lévy Process
equation_latex: phi(u) = exp(i * u * mu * t - 0.5 * sigma^2 * u^2 * t + t * integral_{R} (exp(i * u * x) - 1 - i * u * x * I(|x| < 1)) * nu(dx))
notes: This equation defines the characteristic function of a Lévy process. phi(u) represents the characteristic function
column5: which encodes all information about the process distribution. The Lévy-Khintchine formula shows the decomposition into drift
column6: diffusion

title: Fourier Transform Option Pricing
equation_latex: C = exp(-r * T) * (1/2pi) * integral_{i * infinity}^{-i * infinity} exp(-i * u * ln(K)) * psi(u) / (i * u) du
notes: This equation defines option pricing using Fourier transform methods. C represents the call option price
column5: psi(u) is the characteristic function of log returns
column6: K is the strike
column7: and the integral is over complex u. Fourier methods are efficient for pricing under Lévy processes.

title: Super-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the super-replication price. V_super represents the minimum cost of a hedging strategy that dominates the payoff under all scenarios. In incomplete markets
column5: super-replication is expensive but provides perfect protection.

title: Sub-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the sub-replication price. V_sub represents the maximum value of a hedging strategy that is dominated by the payoff under all scenarios. Sub-replication provides a lower bound on the option price.

title: No-Arbitrage Price Interval
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage price interval in incomplete markets. The market price must lie between the sub-replication and super-replication prices. This interval can be wide in highly incomplete markets
column5: reflecting model uncertainty.

title: Utility-Based Pricing
notes: This equation defines utility-based pricing. V represents the value maximizing expected utility U of consumption
column5: where the expectation is under the physical measure. Utility-based pricing incorporates risk aversion and is used when risk-neutral valuation fails.

title: Indifference Pricing
equation_latex: Indifference Price = E[U(W + payoff - price)] - E[U(W)]
notes: This equation defines the indifference price. The indifference price is the amount that makes the investor indifferent between holding the derivative and not holding it. Indifference pricing depends on the investor's utility function U and initial wealth W.

title: Entropy Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines the entropic risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk-adjusted value of the random payoff X
column5: alpha is the risk aversion parameter. Entropic risk measures are coherent for alpha > 0 and are used for robust optimization.

title: Convex Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines a convex risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk measure
column5: which is the supremum over a set of probability measures Q of the expected loss minus a penalty alpha(Q). Convex risk measures include coherent risk measures as a special case.

title: Robust Optimization
notes: Advanced Topics - Incomplete Markets
column5: This equation defines robust optimization. The objective is to minimize the worst-case cost f(x
column6: theta) over all uncertain parameters theta in the uncertainty set Theta. Robust optimization protects against model misspecification and parameter uncertainty.

title: Ambiguity Aversion
equation_latex: V = inf_{Q in Q} E_Q[payoff] + phi(Q)
notes: This equation defines pricing under model uncertainty (ambiguity aversion). V represents the value
column5: which is the minimum expected payoff over a set of models Q plus a penalty phi(Q) for deviating from the reference model. Ambiguity aversion leads to wider bid-ask spreads.

title: Good-Deal Bounds
notes: This equation defines the good-deal bounds on the market price of risk theta. The bounds restrict the set of equivalent martingale measures to those that are not too extreme. Good-deal bounds narrow the no-arbitrage price interval by excluding unrealistic pricing measures.

title: Minimal Martingale Measure
notes: This equation defines the minimal martingale measure. The minimal martingale measure is the equivalent martingale measure that is closest to the physical measure in terms of relative entropy. It is used when the market price of risk is not uniquely defined.

title: Föllmer-Schweizer Decomposition
notes: This equation defines the Föllmer-Schweizer decomposition. X_t represents the discounted payoff
column5: M_t is a martingale (replicable component)
column6: and A_t is a finite variation process (unreplicable component). The decomposition quantifies the incompleteness of the market.

title: Mean-Variance Hedging
notes: This equation defines mean-variance hedging. The objective is to minimize the mean-squared hedging error between the payoff and the hedge portfolio. Mean-variance hedging is the optimal quadratic hedging strategy in incomplete markets.

title: Quadratic Hedging
notes: This equation defines quadratic hedging with a traded asset S_t and a residual value V_t. The hedge portfolio minimizes the mean-squared hedging error. Quadratic hedging is widely used when perfect hedging is impossible.

title: Market Price of Model Risk
notes: This equation defines the market price of model risk. lambda_model represents the Sharpe ratio of model risk
column5: V_model is the model value
column6: V_true is the true value
column7: and sigma_model is the model uncertainty. Model risk pricing is important for robust valuation.

title: Model Uncertainty
notes: This equation incorporates model risk into pricing. V represents the risk-adjusted value
column5: E_Q[payoff] is the expected payoff under the model
column6: lambda is the market price of model risk
column7: and ModelRisk quantifies the uncertainty in the model. This approach is used in model risk management.

title: Deep Hedging
notes: This equation defines deep hedging using neural networks. Hedge_theta represents the hedging strategy parameterized by theta
column5: which is a neural network taking the market state S_t as input. Deep hedging learns optimal hedging strategies from data without requiring model assumptions.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Option Pricing
column6: Advanced Topics - Incomplete Markets
column7: This equation defines the Bellman equation for optimal stopping. V represents the option value
column8: which is the maximum of immediate exercise and continuation value. Reinforcement learning solves this equation by learning the optimal policy from simulated data.
